Currently, indices can only be a n*2 matrix where the first column is the starting index and the second column is the ending index. It would be nice to extend the indices argument of tf.reduce_slice_*** here to support a vector input. In the case of vector input, the second column of row i will be treated as the first column of row i+1. For example:

indices = [0,5,10,15]

is equivalent to

indices = [ [0,5],
            [5,10],
            [10,15]]

This extension would make tf.reduce_slice_*** more useful. And with this extension, the gradient of tf.repeat would become a very simple like

tf.reduce_slice_sum(grad, tf.scan(lambda a, x: a + x, repeats)))

@zycdragonball I think in your pull request, you can submit a tf.repeat without implementation of gradient. I will extend my ops as described above and you can wait until my extension is done and this PR being merged. What do you think?

body:
Currently, `indices` can only be a `n*2` matrix where the first column is the starting index and the second column is the ending index. It would be nice to extend the `indices` argument of `tf.reduce_slice_***` here to support a vector input. In the case of vector input, the second column of row `i` will be treated as the first column of row  `i+1`. For example:
```python
indices = [0,5,10,15]
``` 

is equivalent to

```python
indices = [ [0,5],
            [5,10],
            [10,15]]
```
This extension would make `tf.reduce_slice_***` more useful. And with this extension, the gradient of `tf.repeat` would become a very simple like
```python
tf.reduce_slice_sum(grad, tf.scan(lambda a, x: a + x, repeats)))
```

@zycdragonball I think in your pull request, you can submit a `tf.repeat` without implementation of gradient. I will extend my ops as described above and you can wait until my extension is done and this PR being merged. What do you think?
